document_title: Congenital pectus excavatum in children: Causes, symptoms, diagnosis
subsection_content:
Concave chest, also known as funnel-shaped chest or sternum concavity, is more common in men than women. If not surgically repaired early, the disease can cause symptoms that affect heart and lung function, and psychologically affect both parents and children. (first)
Congenital pectus excavatum defects form when there is excessive or unbalanced development of the lower costal cartilages, pushing the sternum backward, creating a sudden and deep backward curvature of the sternal body just before the junction. connected to the tip of the sword. Children are often discovered to have sunken breasts right after birth or when they reach puberty. Most cases are detected soon after the child is born.
See more: Pectus excavatum in men: Signs and risk factors
